docs.lead_paragraph: Two studies have found that the use of  S.S.R.I.’s is associated with an increased rate of bone density loss in older people.

headline.main: Aging: Some Antidepressants Tied to Bone Loss, Findings Show
headline.print_headline: Some Antidepressants Tied To Bone Loss, Findings Show

docs.snippet: Two studies have found that the use of  S.S.R.I.’s is associated with an increased rate of bone density loss in older people.

docs.lead_paragraph: Two new studies have found that the use of the antidepressants called S.S.R.I.'s is associated with an increased rate of bone density loss in older people. Researchers studied 2,722 women with an average age of 78, following them for an average of 4.9 years. After adjusting for weight, diet, smoking and other health behaviors, they found that S.S.R.I. users had an average hip bone density decrease of 0.82 percent per year, compared with 0.47 percent per year in nonusers. Decreases among women who used tricyclic antidepressants, an older type, were the same as among those who used no antidepressants at all.

headline.main: Some Antidepressants Tied To Bone Loss, Findings Show

docs.abstract: Two new studies suggests that taking SSRI's, class of antidepressants, may increase rate of bone density loss in older people; research is published in journal Archives of Internal Medicine; drawing (M)
